body.p: This guidance information applies to all staff, contractors and agency staff who work for the .
body.note: If you are national security cleared to 'Enhanced SC' or DV levels, follow this process for all your trips, regardless of whether they are for business or personal reasons.
body.p: As a government official travelling overseas, you should consider that you may be of interest to hostile parties regardless of your role. By following policies and processes, you can help reduce the risk to yourself and limit the damage of exposure of sensitive information.

In general, it is acceptable for users to access services from overseas, and to do this using their equipment. But before you travel, consider:
Do you need to take IT equipment overseas or access IT systems to do your job?
Can the business need be met in another way or by someone else?
If you just need to manage your inbox while away, can you delegate permissions to your inbox to a colleague to manage on your behalf?
Have you left enough time to check and obtain necessary approvals? The process can take several weeks, depending on the circumstances. This is because it may be necessary to apply additional technical controls to protect you, your device, and any data the device can access.

ol.li: Get confirmation from your Line Manager that there is a business need for you to take equipment overseas and access services. Keep a note of the answers you get.

Proceed directly to Part Two of this process if either one of the following two statements apply to you:
You are travelling or passing through one of the following high-attention countries: China, Cyprus, Egypt, India, Iran, Israel, North Korea, Pakistan, Russia, Saudi Arabia, South Africa, South Korea, Syria, Turkey, UAE.
You are national security cleared to 'Enhanced SC' or DV levels.
If you have reached this step, you do not need to seek further formal approval for your trip.
Take a copy of this guidance; it includes useful contact details that help in the event of a problem while travelling.
Check if you need to do anything to prepare for International Roaming.

Collect the following information:
Name.
Email address.
Your business area.
Your Security Clearance.
The network you use to access data, services or applications, for example DOM1 or Quantum, or online services such as AWS or .
The make/type of equipment you want to take with you.
Asset Tag details.
Countries you'll be visiting or passing through.
Dates of travel.
Transport details where possible, for example flights or rail journeys.
Proposed method of connecting, for example VPN, WiFi, or Mobile Data (3G/4G/5G).
Reason for maintaining access while overseas.
The data, applications, or services you expect to access during your trip.
Who you are travelling with.

The next step depends your business area:
If you are part of HQ, HMPPS HQ or HMCTS, contact your Senior Civil Servant (SCS) and ask for approval to take equipment overseas and access services. Ask for any special details or considerations that apply to your proposed travel arrangements. Keep a note of the answers you get.
If you are part of HMPPS (but not HQ), contact your Governor and ask for approval to take equipment overseas and access services. Ask for any special details or considerations that apply to your proposed travel arrangements. Keep a note of the answers you get.
Fill in the overseas travel request form.
Send the completed form to , including the answers obtained from the earlier parts of this process.
Your request is considered, and an answer provided, as quickly as possible.
When you have received all the approvals, send a copy of your request and the approvals to .
When Operational Security have acknowledged receipt of the request and approvals, the formal process is complete.
Check if you need to do anything to prepare for International Roaming .
Take a copy of this guidance; it includes useful contact details that help in the event of a problem while travelling.

body.p: While travelling, you might incur roaming charges when using your equipment for calls or accessing services. These charges can be expensive, and must be paid by your Business Unit. This is another reason for having a good business need to take equipment overseas.

By default, equipment is not enabled for use overseas. Before travelling, contact the Phone and Mobile Devices team. Ask them to enable International Roaming, and to activate the remote wipe function. This helps protect the equipment in case of loss or theft.

topic.title: If you have any problem when using equipment overseas

body.p: Contact the Service Desk immediately. Tell them if the equipment is lost, stolen or was potentially compromised. This includes any time the equipment is deliberately removed out of your sight, such as by a customs official.

If any security-related incident occurs overseas, regardless of whether it involves equipment, you should contact the Operational Security Team as soon as possible. See the guidance on Reporting a Security Incident on the Intranet. This includes information on reporting an incident outside of UK working hours. For convenience, the out-of-hours telephone number for reporting incidents is repeated below.

If there is a problem with your equipment, it might be necessary to disable your ability to connect to the network or services from your device. The Service Desk will do this if required. -issued phones might still have some functionality, to let you make phone calls, but the device should be treated as compromised and not used any more for any business.
